p: M1, encoded from segment 6, is the major structural protein of ICV that lies under the lipid bilayer [ 44, 45]. The internal structure of ICV is dominated by ribonucleoproteins (RNPs) that are composed of ribonucleic acid and four structural proteins. Genome segment 5 codes for nucleoprotein (NP) and segments 1â€“3 code for the polymerase (P) subunits basic (PB)2, PB1, and P3, respectively [ 44, 45, 46]. Segment 6 also encodes CM2 protein, a minor envelope glycoprotein ion channel [ 47]. Segment 7 encodes Non-structural protein 1 (NS1), which inhibits host immune responses and Nuclear Export Protein (NEP), which mediates nuclear export of viral RNP [ 48, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53]. Like other influenza viruses, ICV viruses have a segmented genome capable of reassortment; reassortment has been documented in vitro as well as in vivo among circulating strains [ 54, 55, 56, 57, 58].
